posts.cooked:
Our team is a newbie with Vision this year. We have been reading all the posts about cameras for PhotonVision, and we are unclear as to which exact model to get. Our team is using a Raspberry Pi 4b+. Other posts state that:

ribbon cable is faster than USB

OV9281 is probably the best recommended for PhotonVision

Therefore we purchased a the Innomaker OV9281 ribbon cable camera ( here ) , and the latency is over 80 ms on our pi 4b+ with 4GB RAM because there are limited options for resolutions. We didn’t realize at the time the lack of resolution options. We have to use 1280x800 at 60 FPS as that is the only option high enough to use 3d in PV. The rest are 640x480 or 320x240. Obviously this latency is too great.

Would someone be willing to share the link to the specific camera to use that works well with a pi and PV? We have seen that another team using the Arducam OV9281 USB version ( here ). Is this what works best? Is there not a version of the OV9281 that is a ribbon-cable and has the correct resolution options?
Why is that latency too much for you? What are you trying to do? Settings can be tuned one way or another to change latency but you won’t see like the 1ms latency like in RR tape.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
meepleBot:

Our team is a newbie with Vision this year.

meepleBot:

Obviously this latency is too great.

Would definitely recommend a bit more research into some of the vision topics before assuming. For what its worth, our team is planning to hit the field with Innomaker OV9281’s at mid or high resolution, with 300ms+ latency.

The key: we’re compensating for latency in how we feed vision pose estimates in the WPILib kalman filter.

254’s presentation on the topic is an excellent introduction, particuarly slides 33-35.

link_counts.title: Integrating Computer Vision with Motion Control | Team 254

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked:
At that resolution, with a Pi 4, you won’t be able to do much better. You’re simply processor limited. Try increasing decimate and see how that impacts your pose estimation and latency. Sometimes higher resolution with a decimate can work well at long range.

You can also try fusing multiple tags into a single pose estimation to greatly improve accuracy, but that’s not built into PV yet (I think?).

Our assumption that the latency we are seeing is too great is based on following all the work other teams have been doing in the offseason this fall/winter on PhotonVision. All the latency numbers we have seen people posting are smaller than what we are seeing (sometimes much smaller), which led us to believe that we need to get our numbers down to be useful. We are a lower-resourced team and don’t yet have all our parts to make a drivetrain functional enough to do more testing on our own. Also our practice space is a narrow hallway, and we likely won’t be on a field or anything close to even a half-field until our first competition. It will be difficult for us to see if our system is going to really work until our first competition. We are trying to “learn from the best” by following what others are doing. It is very helpful for us to see other teams will have latencies around 300ms as now we know our assumption was wrong and may be fine for our use.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
meepleBot:

may be fine for our use.

Gotcha, that’s some good context.

So yea, historically, there’s been two ways to interpret vision processing results.

One is to completely ignore latency, and just trust that when the camera tells you something, it’s “basically right now”. This is the simple strategy, and one Limelight helped push forward big time a few years back. It’s still the easiest way to get started. 80ms is right on that threshold of “probably negligible” - your code runs every 20ms, so that’s only like 3-4 loops behind. 150-200 is where you’d probably start to see bigger issues. Specifically, the most common symptom is not being able to tune your drivetrain PID gains very high before oscillation occurs.

The hardware way (that I’m referring to, and which is detailed in the 254 paper) is to remember a short history of where your robot has been for the past second or so. Then, when a vision measurement comes in with some latency, go back in that buffer of history to correct the point at which the vision measurement came in, and “replay” the samples after that with the adjustment. The latest in the buffer is still what you use for controlling the robot’s drivetrain.

The jury is still out on whether apriltags can be processed fast enough to use the old “ignore-latency” method. Certainly lowering resolution and increasing decimation helps (to the point where you can see ~60-80ms latencies on photonvision even on older Pi’s). However, what I honestly don’t know is whether with the speed optimizations, the accuracy at distance is still good enough to be useful on a real field. I sure hope it is, but I’m not yet hanging my hat on that being for-sure-true.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked:
meepleBot:

All the latency numbers we have seen people posting are smaller than what we are seeing (sometimes much smaller),

Yes, at lower resolution. Most tests are run at 640x480 decimate 1 to make benchmarking easier. You’re running quadruple the number of pixels.

If you want to play it super safe, run 640x480 Decimate 2 and just run 2d detection at close range (16ft or less). You’ll get excellent performance. Also, overclock your pi to 2GHz and add a cooler.

posts.name: Lidor Kaplan
Matt
posts.cooked: I have code from ApriltagWorkbench here, that you’re able to copy paste: GitHub - mcm001/photonvision at multiag-pnp Still isn’t quite yet into PhotonPoseEstimator

posts.name: Lidor Kaplan
posts.cooked: Thanks for sharing, do we know when it’ll be officialy merged to PhotonVision? (In general, and to PhotonPoseEstimator specifically)

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked:
When my fluid mechanics homework stops sucking all my free time up <3

If you wanna see a feature the fastest way to get it is to contribute!

gerthworm:

150-200 is where you’d probably start to see bigger issues.

@gerthworm This info is all very helpful! We have been reading all the theory behind using vision and generally understand it, but as first-timers with vision and limitations on the size of our practice space for testing it is hard to know what the line is between acceptable latency and where more complex code needs to be written to correct for it.

gerthworm:

Specifically, the most common symptom is not being able to tune your drivetrain PID gains very high before oscillation occurs.

At this point we aren’t planning to use PID on our drivetrain to align on a target as we are using a differential drive, which limits our maneuverability. Rather we plan/hope to use PoseEstimation  with PV to auto-drive to certain targets within the Community. We hope that our updates to the Pose with the AprilTag info will be accurate enough to allow us to do this.
